definitions.definition: a strong feeling of shock and anger

examples.text: The judge's remarks caused public outrage.
She was filled with a strong sense of **moral outrage**.
Environmentalists have expressed outrage at the ruling.
Much of the outrage was directed at foreign nationals.
Shopkeepers voiced their outrage at the new tax.
The announcement provoked howls of outrage.
The guests all shouted in outrage.
The news was greeted with outrage.

definitions.definition: an act or event that is violent, cruel or very wrong and that shocks people or makes them very angry

examples.text: No one has yet claimed responsibility for this latest terrorist outrage.
The new law on pensions is an outrage against the elderly.
the outrages committed by the invading army

wordOrigin: Middle English (in the senses ‘lack of moderation’ and ‘violent behaviour’): from Old French ou(l)trage, based on Latin ultra ‘beyond’. Sense development has been affected by the belief that the word is a compound of out and rage.
